node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.title: Crypto: will the bitcoin dream succeed?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and road.

node.text:
Madagascar is reeling from a double catastrophe: crop failure in the south, partly due to climate change, and a covid-19-induced economic crunch. This has brought the country to the brink of famine.⁠
⁠
Malnutrition, though always a big problem, was until recently improving. Many children are now dropping out of school to work or forage for food. ⁠
⁠
Covid-19 has kneecapped the economy. The World Bank expected it to grow 5.2% in 2020; instead it shrank by 4.2%.⁠
⁠
Some investors worry about Madagascar’s stability. Two decades ago it came close to civil war, and the army has intervened regularly in politics.⁠
⁠
Without short-term aid, many children will grow up with stunted bodies and minds. To help families feed themselves in the long run, Madagascar needs to develop. Tap the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Majority World/Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 01, 2021. May be art.

node.text:
Trading in Japanese government bonds is drying up. There have been few negative market consequences. ⁠
⁠
Once-frenetic trading desks in Tokyo have fallen silent over the past half-decade. Such a lull in the world’s second-largest market for sovereign bonds would once have been remarkable.⁠
⁠
Sceptics of the Bank of Japan's enormous quantitative-easing programme warned this moment would come. Yet concerns about the functioning of the government-bond market have yet to be realised. ⁠
⁠
It also says something interesting about quantitative easing and monetary policy in general. Tap the link in our bio to find out what the lessons might be for other countries.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @satillustration

node.text:
The trial of Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes has refocused attention on Silicon Valley. On our podcast “Checks and Balance” we investigate the unique challenges facing San Francisco, and ask why the city is so poorly governed.⁠
⁠
The pandemic exposed San Francisco’s problems—and how it responds will determine its future. Matt Haney, a city official, says the home of innovation is at an existential moment in its history. The local economy is stuttering as tech workers stay home. Emigration, crime, and poorly-run schools need fixing, just as a series of recall elections are causing political instability.⁠
⁠
To find out why San Francisco may feel the impacts of the pandemic for longer, click the link in our bio to listen to “Checks and Balance”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " In the past 20 years America has been prone to a policy of 'unfinished business' Marwan Muasher'.

node.text:
The end of America’s “unipolar moment” was bound to come sooner or later, says Marwan Muasher of Carnegie Endowment.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Writing for The Economist, the former foreign minister and deputy prime minister of Jordan argues that “Pax Americana has not worked. America has tired of enforcing it, and Arab countries are tired of having it imposed on them to their detriment.” ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
No American president, it seems, is prepared to entertain an alternative policy: a complex effort to support a serious process of reform in the Arab world, he adds. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Despite its waning interest, Mr Muasher explains that America’s declining influence does not make the road to stability and prosperity any easier.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read why Mr Muasher thinks that Arab populations need to stand up for their rights more assertively, tap the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

This captivating photograph of a Leafy Seadragon camouflaged in the shallow reefs of the Fleurieu Peninsula has won the 2021 Australian Geographic Nature Photographer of the Year competition.

Photographers from around the world have submitted their nature and wildlife photographs from the bioregion of Australia, New Zealand, Antarctica and New Guinea. Swipe through to see some of our favourites.

And for the best of our journalism and analysis on science, tap the link in our bio to sign up for our Simply Science newsletter.

node.text:
Though affiliates like al-Shabab have celebrated the Taliban’s victory in Afghanistan, al-Qaeda’s central organisation has not said a word.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But the violent jihadist Islamism it pioneered has not been defeated. Al-Qaeda affiliates and other jihadist groups are active in conflicts not just in Pakistan and the Middle East but across the African Sahel and in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The ability to mount outrages like that of September 11th has apparently been curtailed by better intelligence, pressure on finances and a drumbeat of raids and drone strikes. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But jihadist doctrines continue to inspire attacks by loner jihadists in America and Europe, though currently not at the rate seen in the mid-2010s.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read why America’s flight from Afghanistan will embolden jihadists around the world, tap the link in our bio.

node.text:
New rules in China state that, in order to “effectively protect the physical and mental health of minors”, children under 18 can play online video games only between 8pm and 9pm on Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays.⁠
⁠
The limits are the most restrictive in the world, and will affect tens of millions of people.⁠
⁠
As well as affecting players, the producers of these games will be hit—whether local or foreign.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how this is part of a technology crackdown that is reckoned to have already wiped more than $1trn off the value of the country’s biggest tech firms.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'The trial of Elizabeth Holmes She was once touted as the next Stene Steve Jobs. NOw she is battling fraud charges'.

node.text:
The story of Elizabeth Holmes, who founded Theranos in 2003 as a 19-year-old university dropout, is an epic of Silicon Valley hubris.⁠
⁠
She brought glamour and charisma to the corporate world, adorning magazine covers as the subject of flattering features within.⁠
⁠
The startup attempted to revolutionise the process of blood testing. Ms Holmes’s relentless promotion of her firm’s potential led to a valuation of $9bn in 2015, but it failed spectacularly in 2016 after the press and regulators probed the company’s inflated claims.⁠
⁠
Now, Ms Holmes could face jail. But to read why the buzz over Theranos stems from more than money, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Jeff Chiu/AP/Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 31, 2021. May be a cartoon of 4 people and text that says 'Business What will the meetings of the future look like? D'.

node.text:
Grand lobbies with water features or video walls have previously shaped first impressions when walking into company offices.⁠
⁠
In the age of covid-19 video calls set the tone.⁠
⁠
With workers stuck at home, anything that used to involve people crowding into spaces, from performance reviews to shareholder jamborees, moved to cyberspace.⁠
⁠
Now that many firms are reopening their premises, they are rethinking their approach to meetings. Managers must decide which parts of the remote experience, if any, they want to keep. ⁠
⁠
But hybrid meetings where some people are present in person and others dial in present a particular challenge. ⁠
⁠
Virtual meetings are not going anywhere. But tap the link in our bio to learn why, as with all work that is partly remote and partly not, the future of meetings looks messy.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @d_urbo_design

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, motorcycle, outdoors and text that says 'Finance & economics The economy that could not be stopped by the pandemic HOTEL M'.

node.text:
Integration with global manufacturing has helped keep Vietnam’s economy humming during the pandemic. In 2020 GDP rose by 2.9% even as most countries recorded deep recessions.⁠
⁠
As the rest of East Asia developed and wages there rose, global manufacturers were lured by Vietnam’s low labour costs and stable exchange rate. That fuelled an export boom.⁠
⁠
Now the government wants Vietnam to become a high-income country by 2045, a task that requires growing at 7% a year.⁠
⁠
But as Vietnam develops, sustaining rapid growth from exports of foreign companies will become increasingly difficult. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read more about how Vietnam's economy has so far withstood a pandemic-induced recession.⁠
⁠
Credit: Linh Pahm/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " America is the architect of a durable political, economic and security order that has made it and others safer Kori Schake'.

node.text:
America has a government created by people who distrusted government, and is a great power whose people would prefer to remain uninvolved in the world, says Kori Schake. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Writing for The Economist, the director of foreign and defense policy at the American Enterprise Institute argues that “those anomalies make it difficult to sustain international commitments, especially involving countries not constituted along similar domestic lines.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
And yet America is the architect of a durable political, economic and security order that has made it and others safer and more prosperous, she adds. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“The global order should not be taken for granted,” she writes. “Its genius is that it benefits not just America and its allies but every country that plays by its rules. And it is especially beneficial to middle-sized and smaller powers.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If America cannot or will not uphold the international, rules-based system, the likeliest outcomes will be either a frayed, more chaotic world, or one dominated by China, she warns. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠To read why Ms Schake thinks America should strengthen the global system it created—not give up on it, click the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.text:
Assigning an individual to a species is for the most part pretty straightforward. Finding something which defines a species is impossible.⁠
⁠
At the moment, about 1.2m species have been given recognised scientific names. This is certainly an underestimate of the real figure but the number says little about what species actually are.⁠
⁠
For example, Darwinism explains a huge amount about life, and about species. But it still does not say where the juncture is which marks a species-defining common ancestor.⁠
⁠
Species may look like natural categories. But their definition depends as much on what you are interested in saying about them as on the biology behind the answer.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read about the origins of "species" and why the term, though widely used, is hard to define.⁠
⁠
You can learn more in the fifth of six guides to biology that we're publishing. Next week we'll be looking at living planets. To better understand living planets, coming back down to earth and understanding species helps. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @danieliev
